title: Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis electroporation
article_citation: Swafford AJM, Hussey SP, Fritz-Laylin LK, High-efficiency electroporation of chytrid fungi. Scientific Reports doi: 10.1038/s41598-020-71618-2

source.description: Make 50 mL SM buffer (SM buffer should not be more than 7 days old).
SM Buffer:
Make an appropriate volume of Paraformaldehyde fixation buffer.

Make 2mg/mL dextrans in SM buffer (Be sure it is Cat No. D3305 from Invitrogen by Thermo Fisher Scientific)
  • dextrans is sticky, measure in the tube you will be adding buffer to.
  • Spin down at high speed, then use supernatant.
Measure out the required amount of autoclaved growth media into an appropriate flask.
Place fixation buffer, growth media, and bonner's salts on ice.
Transfer synced cells to 50mL conicals
Resuspend in 10 mL of SM buffer, combine after resuspension if multiple tubes were needed to hold all the synced spores.

SM for each cuvette)
Count cell concentration. Aiming for 2x107 - 1x107 cells/mL
If the spores are overly concentrated, dilute to the appropriate concentration.

Prepare cuvettes & tubes.
E- = electroporation control (no voltage)
D- = Dextrans control (no dextrans)
Prepare E-D- tubes. 1.5mL eppendorfs:
Preprare E-D+ tubes: 1.5ml eppendorfs
Prepare E+D- cuvettes: 0.2cm electroporation cuvettes
Prepare E+D+ cuvettes: 0.2cm electroporation cuvettes
Set samples on ice for ~ 10 minutes
Set electroporation protocol

• Squarewave protocol
  • 1000V
  • 2 pulses
  • 5 sec intervals
  • 2mm cuvette
Insert cuvette
Hit the PULSE button, record percent droop
Remove cuvette and place immediately on ice.

materials.name: Gene Pulser Electroporation Cuvettes, 0.2 cm gap

description: Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (BD) is a parasitic symbiote with many frogs. BD infection is devastating to most frog species, causing mass mortality in ~6.5% of amphibian species. To understand the cellular biology of BD and its interaction with amphibians, we have developed an method of electroporation, allowing for efficient deliver of extracellular constructs to infectious BD zoospores. The current method reliably loads 95% of treated cells with extracellular dextrans.
